title: How we can factorize a^3-1÷a^3-2a+2÷a? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let us space this out a little bit to make it more accessible. a^3 - (1/a^3) - 2a + 2/a. Ok. Let us see if we can see some identities here. (1/a^3) can be written as (1/a)^3. And now we can apply the identity a^3 - b^3 = (a-b)(a^2 + b^2 + ab). And we can also take -2 common out of the last two terms. a^3 - (1/a)^3 - 2 (a- 1/a) Apply the a^3 - b^3 identity- (a - 1/a) ( a^2 + 1/a^2 + a*1/a) - 2(a- 1/a) So now, we can take the a- 1/a term common out of the two terms. (a- 1/a) (a^2 + 1/a^2 + 1 -2) and we get- (a- 1/a) (a^2 + 1/a^2 -1) There you have it.
